title: Italian overture
text:
The Italian overture is a piece of <a href="orchestra">orchestra</a>l <a href="music">music</a> which opened several <a href="opera">opera</a>s, <a href="oratorio">oratorio</a>s and other large-scale works in the late 17th and early 18th centuries.
An Italian overture typically has a three-<a href="movement%20%28music%29">movement</a> structure – the outer movements are quick, the middle movement is slow.
This type of overture was particularly popular among Italian composers such as <a href="Alessandro%20Scarlatti">Alessandro Scarlatti</a>, and in the early 18th century would usually be called "<a href="sinfonia">sinfonia</a>". Later, to avoid confusion with other types of sinfonia/<a href="symphony">symphony</a>, the term "Italian overture" was used more frequently.
The structure of the Italian overture/sinfonia was the base from which the <a href="Classical%20period%20%28music%29">classical</a> <a href="multi-movement">multi-movement</a> cycle - used in genres including the <a href="symphony">symphony</a>, <a href="concerto">concerto</a>, and <a href="sonata">sonata</a> - developed around the middle of the 18th century. For more about the (18th century) relationship between "Italian" overtures, other types of overtures (e.g. the "<a href="French%20overture">French overture</a>") and early symphonies, see <a href="sinfonia">sinfonia</a>.
